title: Heated Build Platform 1.1 adapters for Cupcake

description.text:
Amazed by the extra-rigid piece of aluminium and the extremely limited heated build platform 1.0 of my Cupcake, I decided to buy the Thing-o-matic HBP and then adapt it to my printer. All sorts of strange designs came to my mind, and finally I got what I think was the most simple and effective solution: printing 4 extra corners and use one of the wood platforms used for the X stage of the printer. What will you get?
  • An extra plain build surface
  • Forgot about the aluminium sticker
  • More uniform temperature distribution
  • Improved build size
    • Of course, this mod is compatible with the amazing XY lowrider by twotimes!

• Remove the HBP 1.0 from the cupcake
  • Print 4 corners and then screw them to your each corner of your cupcake platform wood piece.
  • Screw the HBP 1.1 to each corner
  • Reinstall the platform wood piece and start to print!
    • I recommend printing this mod in ABS since probably PLA will melt due to the temperatures the HBP gets during the printing process.

comments.text: will this also work on the stock cupcake xy without the xy low rider? I'm just in the process of building and printing the a slew of upgrades and hoping this might make the stepstruder print easier. thx
comments.author: fyrebug

comments.text: Yes, it should work, as it uses the included platform both for the lowrider and the included XY stage
comments.author: fyrebug

comments.text: Could use a bit more explanation - did you have to modify your RepG profile at all? It would seem like you could have issues with this if you run endstops...
comments.author: msmollin

comments.text: I din't modify the RepG profile. My cupcake still thinks that the platform is 100x100mm. The only problem is to get the white connector that will plug the new HBP to the Gen3 hardware, but a visit to the electronics store solves it in 3 minutes.
comments.author: msmollin

comments.text: I was just about to go do this after observing tat my cupcake has about 110mm travel in all directions
comments.author: tetnum

comments.text: You can't use all the surface with an unmodded cupcake but the point is the temperature distribution. With the HBP 1.1 it's more uniform and you can really print 10x10 objects without warping at the edges.
comments.author: tetnum

comments.text: Awesome

description.text:
I have a Bodum coffee press, unfortunately the enclosure that held the glass was made of very cheap plastic and had a flimsy design which broke almost immediately.

This design is intended to address the structural issues while maintaining the original aesthetic of the press.

The bottom is now flat so there's no warping of the case when you press the coffee, and a second ring has been added to thew bottom for added stability.

The design is intended to accommodate the original coffee press handle but should be compatible with Bodum CAFFETTIERA, CHAMBORD, or any similar press.

title: CTC / Flashforge Kabel und Filament Halter

description.text:
CTC / Flashforge Kabel und Filament Halter.
Kann mit 4mm PTFE oder M6 Pushbuttons genutzt werden. Für die M6 Pushbuttons sollte noch ein Gewinde eingedreht werden. Zur Befestigung habe ich M3 genutzt. Passt bei meinem CTC in die vorgebohrten Löcher. Scheinbar gibt es hier verschiedene Versionen der CTCs. Solltet Ihr andere Maße benötigen könnt Ihr auf Onshape eine Kopie davon machen und individuell anpassen. Sucht in Public Docs nach CTC 3D Parts. Ein PDF mit den wichtigsten Maßen ist auch dabei.

Info(Auf den Fotos ist noch eine Version mit 75mm zu sehen, das STL hat aber 45mm Armlänge)

Really impressed. Printed this for my daughter. Prints in one piece but still has moving hinged butterfly wings. Moves beautiful with no hint of sticking.
Lovely gossamer wing design.
comments.author: Spongebob1969

comments.text: I love this, but wasn't able to print it.  Tried 2x, once with the base, once without.  With the base - can't get the base off of it, it hardens so fast that the base won't come off without breaking the wings and/or antennas.  If I leave the base on, it doesn't look right and the wings won't move.  When I tried without the base, it doesn't stay in place on the platform - as the printer moves, the butterfly starts to move and shift around as well and it eventually just breaks.  Maybe it's something in my settings ??
comments.author: rstinnett

comments.text: When I made this I was using an acrylic platform and prints stick really well to that even without a raft base. Now I'm using glass with blue painter's tape on it and I have trouble getting things to stick without a raft, for most models. I'd suggest either trying a stickier plate (?) or maybe trying hairspray, which some people say makes things work better. The raft base is definitely going to cause a problem like you said so somehow get stickier! :)
comments.author: rstinnett

comments.text: Love this model!  I printed a couple, but what is the secret to getting the hinge to hinge?  Mine is fused in one piece.  I'm printing in PLA which loves to stick to itself, so my hinged butterfly is just one piece.  I like it already, but I'd love it if someone can give me a hint.

comments.text: It helped me to use .2mm layer height. More or less and the hinge seemed more likely to stick together. Also it is important to print it without supports. Then somehow some kind of magic happens in that hinge and it works!

You were 100% correct!! I went to .2 layer height and turned up my cooling fan and Viola - the next print hinged with little effort to break it free. It was "like magic".
Thanks for your words of wisdom.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a Dustfilter for the MakerBot SmartExtruder+ for the Replicator Z18.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 - 0.15mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Print "...Top6" with support and "...Buttom6/7" without support. You have to turn 'em a bit.
Check the instructions below.

Printing

"Top" File:

Rotate it 45° on the x-axis. Move it on platform and center. Use the default settings high (possible to change layer height to 0.15mm) add support.

"Bottom" File:

Rotate it -135° on the x-axis. Move it on platform. Use the default settings high (possible to change layer height to 0.15mm). Post-Printing 1. Remove the supports. 2. Remove the swivel-clip and push out the ball bearing. 3. Place it into the printed one... Lay it on the table and push it inside. 4. Place the sponge and add some oil. 5. Take the top, hold it as shown in the picture... and turn it 180°. 6. Thats it! Your swivel clip-dust filter is now ready to be pushed on the smart extruder+ Z18.

File Updates

(There was a fault in the thread and others..)
Removed all previous files and added the newest ones.

Other parts you need: You need a o-ring rubber for fixation.

Note: I only printed V2 (asymmetric), because you can print it without any support.

description.text:
I converted a "Solar Garden Light" from Harbor Freight (One Stop Gardens - Item#60561) into a light that hangs on a toilet bowl and illuminates it for night use.

Designed mostly as a gag, but other vendors are making big bucks on this, so if you have a spare broken solar light kit (where the electronics are still good, or you are kibbling several together). I have a somewhat dark bathroom during the day, so I don't get a great charge, and I have no idea how long a regular AA battery will last, but that's not recommended unless you don't add the solar panel, and then the circuit won't turn off during daylight.

I used translucent filament for the "span", and GITD for box and cover. The logo doesn't seem to slice very well.
Another simple dock for iPad Mini or similar thickness devices

title: Plant Space Rocket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Bring plants or plant seeds into space!

This new Plant Space Rocket uses elements of "Voronoi LED toadstool tealight shade" by @funkshin (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1371598) and the "Flying saucer" from @gpvillamil (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10428/).



Good to know:

  • Print the ring with wall and floor thickness 5. Glue the ring on the bottom part of the rocket. So you can easily open and close the rocket.

  • At the top of the rocket, I melted a hole out.

Printed with PLA.



Update:

12.06.2016: Added "Plant-Space-Rocket-Unten_NEW_optimized.stl".

10.05.2016: Released two new versions. The "Mini Plant Space Rocket with Pot" https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1548463 and the "Big Plant Space Rocket with Pot" https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1548574.

22.04.2016: I made a small planting pot (Plant-Space-Rocket-4cm_Pot_NEW.stl), which can be used instead of the ring.

02.04.2016: I made a new Ring (Plant-Space-Rocket-Ring_NEW.stl). This should be easier to print.
.
28.03.2016: I made a new rocket bottom part (Plant-Space-Rocket-Unten_NEW.stl). The printing will be cleaner and the three standing feet are much stronger.


------------------------

If you have no 3D-printer, you can buy a printed copy here:
www.shapeways.com/product/NGKBY466W/

title: E3D V6 Mount with Fan for CTC / Flashforge / Replicator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wasn't really satisfied with the available E3D V6 Mounts for my CTC, so I created my own version.
There are 2 Versions available - they are all the same, but different!

I would hardyl recommend V003 for single or V007 for dual setup.

For assembly you will need 4 M3 nuts, 2 M3x30 screws (head-style doesn't matter, but the designs are for countersunk), 2-4 screws to mount the 40 mm fan, 2 M3x20 screws to mount the whole thing to the extruder carriage and one push-in fitting for the 4mm (OD) bowden tube.
For the extruder I used the standard springloaded extruder and mounted it using the 000 parts on the back (the CTC already has the correct mounting holes).

The current Version for a single extruder conversion is V003.
The current Version for a dual extruder setup is V007 - you can choose to use my part cooler design or just use your own. The left hotend has around 1 mm play for hight-adjustment.

Update 07.02.2016

I just added a .rar with all released models as .stp-files

Printer:

CTC 3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25 %, 4 Shells

Notes:

I only used support on the bridge part to keep the Mounting for the hot end smooth.

The horizontal nozzle-distance is 36 mm (in Software, make sure to measure the actual value). You have to attach the extruder mount on the top-most position of the back panel of your printer - otherwise it may interfere with your spools / spool holder.

author: smartformat

description.text: I was reading a guide on how to make paracord bracelets and noticed the guy had a loom made of wood to hold the cord tight while he did the weave. I thought it would make a neat 3D printing project for some nifty hobby synergy. Uses basic M3 hardware to make an adjustable loom. More info in instructions. Comments always welcome!

Print 2 brackets and 2 sliders with whatever settings work best for you. I used 2 shells and 10% infill. Place M3 nuts in the slots on the underside of the slider. I used some blue tape laying around to hold them in better but you don't need it. Slide slider over bracket and thread an M3x30 screw through and hold it in with an M3 nut in the slot. Don't tighten too much yet. Place clip over holes and hold in place with 2 M3x20 screws (slightly shorter might work, maybe 15 being the min, longer than 20 might get wonky). Clip brackets onto a thin table or piece of wood, I used my sliding keyboard rack on my desk. Adjust sliders to length you want and tighten M3x30 screw to hold into place. Here is the PDF guide I got the idea from http://www.operationgratitude.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/HowtoMakeaParacordSurvivalBracelet.pdf you can see on bottom of page 3 where the loom comes in.

title: Ammonoidea Clock - Continuous Clock - Linear Clock

description.text:
I've seen this great clock at the Roues Libres exhibition during Designers’ Days 2014 in Paris (Designer Boaz Cohen and Sayaka Yamamoto - BCXSY [1]) and I was thinking: I have to built my own personal version of this fascinating clock. I first built the clock in wood (more than 0.5 m in height) but it was to heavy for a cheap clockwork. Now with a 3D-printer I was able to design and print a lighter one which works with cheap clockworks for 1-2 Euro. The ammonoidea-shaped pointer is fitted at the clockwork-indicator position for the hour-pointer.

What else you need: A standard clockwork (I used this one: http://www.ebay.de/itm/Weiss-Quarz-Uhrwerk-Movement-Quartzuhrwerk-Mechanism-Mit-3-Zeigersaetzen-4-/141287149980?ssPageName=ADME:L:OU:DE:3160 )

Note: You should print the lines and numbers with a lower scaling factor (for fitting in the housing)

Other remarks:

  • Ammonoidea = fossil snail
  • [1] http://www.gizmodo.com.au/tags/linear-cycle/
  • Because of the size of my printer (220x220x230mm) the numbers are a bit too small to read (height only 5.2 mm). But who cares?! It's art and beautiful to look at. :)

author: widddo

description.text:
The BCN3D+ came with a blower fan which efficiently cool down the electronics, but it can be really noise up to 55 dB. So I change this set up for an option of 2 or 3 axial fans with run much quite, around 40 dB.
I have been using this set up with 2 fan pointing to the mosfet and the steeper motor driver and it works fine but for extra cooling you can add the third fan.

Material list:
1x 3D printed fan holder BCN3D
3x 12V 40x40x10 axial fan
2x DIN912 M3x10 (to hold the 3D printed part in the machine)
6x DIN912 M3x20 (to hold the fan in the 3D printed part)
6x DIN934 M3

You can buy this fan for example here -> http://www.ebay.es/itm/Ventilador-12V-Fan-40x40x10mm-FAN-CPU-enfriador-cooler-p-PC-ordenador-silencio-/251629967132?hash=item3a9650971c:g:NYYAAOSwEK9T~utU

description.text: Just created this wonderful looking de Laval nozzle for testing propose

comments.text: Here's a "Combustion Chamber" to add to the nozzle for a scale model biprop rocket engine: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:868238
comments.author: ddThingz

comments.text: very nice! This is a great idea. Thanks for sharing :)
comments.author: ddThingz

comments.text: This is great. I made one to show during our "spacecraft propulsion" session in my annual Basics of Interplanetary Flight course with Art Center College of Design. I used to use an actual rocket engine, about the same size as this one, but years ago it became unavailable. Nice to have a physical object to handle, over and above viewgraphs and images and arm waving! (But I don't think it would stand up to supersonic choked-flow hot gas : - )
comments.author: ddThingz

comments.text: so just a cooling fan? It is impossible to achieve supersonic flow with that type of fan. The pressure is not high enough for the exit velocity. I am trying to get a shop vac to go supersonic and even that is doubtful! what were you testing? I love aerodynamics and fluid mechanics!
comments.author: theapplepi

comments.text:
hi there, we made this just for testing in low air speeds. Problem with this design is that the smallest point of the nozzle is way too small. Only thing that happens is that it stops most of the air moving out of the nozzle.
I guess it could work if the air speed would be super sonic. I guess it would be useful to print this nozzle in metal and use a rocket engine.
comments.author: theapplepi

comments.text: I noticed for my van de laval that if the speeds are non-supersonic the exhaust is quite turbulent and the velocity is very time dependent. If you were not testing for mach >1 what were you testing? I do not know of any other use for the particular design. Were you trying to achieve supersonic speeds by contracting the nozzle like crazy (that is what I tried with the shop vac. at a certain point even that has a hole lower limit and by decreasing the diameter of the hole it decreased the velocity)?

title: Robo 3D R1 60mm Ramps cooling fan adapter

description.text:
This is an adapter I made to to replace the 40mm ramps cooling fan on the bottom of the Robo3D printer. Space is tight, so this adapter holds the new 60mm fan partially suspended below the bottom plate. The top of the fan is now no higher than the original fan.

Determine your location, mark and cut a 60.2mm hole in the bottom plate. Mount the fan, the tape is only holding the wires in place. the fan is a tight press press fit in the adapter. Plug the fan back into the existing fan connection and reinstall the bottom plate.

Make sure you have a 12 volt fan, Printer extension feet are required (thing 217346).

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

Yes

No

medium

40%

Those were the settings from my last print job. You could get by with less infill, your choice.

This is a thumb ring designed to help hold a book open when reading one-handed. It is not ornate. I kept it simple and functional. The thumb hole is 33mm in diameter. The thumb ring is not designed to fit snuggly around the thumb so the model is "one-size-fits-all". If the ring hole proves too small, you could scale the entire model up without loss of functionality. The pictured model was printed in ABS in medium quality mode with a 30% fill. I would imagine PLA and other printing parameters would have no real effect on the basic functioning of the ring. The ring can be worn one of two ways; with the ring side toward the book, or away from the book (as pictured). Both work well and your choice should be a matter of comfort. I have included both stl and obj files. I should say that the design is inspired by a recent Instructable (http://www.instructables.com/id/How-make-a-reader-ring-with-Sugru/). Enjoy your reading.

designed in TinkerCad
sliced in Cura
printed in ABS
layer height 0.2mm
wall thickness 0.8mm
fill density 30%
temperature 260
print speed 50mm/s

I ran into a Replicator at the Microsoft shop at the Fashion Valley mall and saw the cool Dodeca Chain Loops found here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:31925. I'm getting a little better with Sketchup so I figured hey, I can make something like that. The basic shape is a alt text heart (alt+3) entered as 3d text, offset, and then extruded. It is designed to print at .2mm layer thickness with solid infill and single wall thickness. I was able to get mine to separate without the need for any cutting and no support material. Aside from some simple name plaques this is the first thing I actually designed and printed from scratch for a purpose. I included the Sketchup file in case anyone wants to make it longer/shorter. The pieces in the middle are all the same, but I had to do a custom connection on the 3 that are on the end to make the loop.

description.text:
Early development state of a weather station you can print with your 3D printer  
For the Anemometer you need three half table tennis balls, two ball bearings, a threared rod, some screw nuts, one magnet and one hall sensor. There are holes for mounting the Hall Sensor PCB  
For the tipping bucket rain gauge you need one magnet and one Hall sensor (there is no mounting yet)

comments.text: I'm putting one of these together and and thought I'd throw this out there for anyone else wondering how to calculate the wind speed.

comments.author: ben2150

comments.text: I'm in the process of building a weather station, and I like your compact anemometer. I was curious about the circuit you designed to measure the speed of the rotation. I understand you're using a Hall latch, but is there anything you do to the rod so that it triggers the latch? From the picture, it seems that you have just a threaded rod over the hall sensor, and I was wondeirng if that's all you used to get a reading.
comments.author: kd0skh

comments.text:
You need to stick a magnet to the rod and measure how often it passes the sensor in one minute to get the rpm of the rod.
There is probably a way to use the area of the scoops, the length of the arms and the rpm reading to calculate the wind speed...

title: BMW E46 Tape Deck / Cassette Smartphone Holder (Especially LG Nexus 5)

description.text:
For all who won't get rid of the BMW E46 Cassette Radio (Maybe it's the DVD Navigation System) there is a way to use the Tape Deck again.

This holder fits for all Smartphones smaller than 72mm and thinner than 10mm.

There is a hole at the bottom for sticking a Micro USB cable throug. I would not have a cable permanently attached to the holder.

I use it for the LG Nexus 5 and applied some felt pads for a tight fit.

There a 3 versions:
-Standard
-Standard with BMW logo
-Short version for not-covering the air outlet

I recommend using ABS, because the inside of the car maybe gets to hot in summer for PLA.

title: Parking dual extruder, Prusa i3 X axis mod, hexagon extruders

description.text:
This is my design of a dual carriage system. I am using two electromagnets 12V 20N for picking up an extruder and for parking i disable the electromagnet so that the permanent magnet located in the X-axis (left and right side parts) holds the carriage in place.
While parked the extruder does not ooze, because an aluminium plate closes the nozzle opening.

STL and Solidworks part are included.
Please see my youtube video for the carriages in action!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FiTmRHkiEUg

Update:
Electric scheme is based on this scheme (thanks to 3d-proto):
http://www.3d-proto.de/public/img/DualParkExtSetup.png.
Pay attention to the direction of diode D1 and D2 that are placed parallel to your electromagnets. Switching hotend fans with relays is optional of course.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Print the carriages in ABS, because they are close to the hotend and the electromagnets get hot.
Support structures are needed.

1x Ultra micro servo
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__31634__HK_282A_Single_Screw_Ultra_Micro_Servo_2g_0_2kg_0_08sec_EU_Warehouse_.html

1x 5V two channel relay
http://www.ebay.com/itm/5V-Two-2-Channel-Relay-Module-With-optocoupler-For-PIC-AVR-DSP-ARM-Arduino-/181026509345

2x Diode 1000V/1A

{IF NEWTOOL=1} G1 X232.000 F6500 ; go to right parking lot

comments.text: So it's not a bistable latching mechanism?  I had assumed 2 permanent magnets. 1 to keep stuck at right. 1 to keep stuck at left. The electromagnet temporarily is used to overcome the separation forced required.  In which case the electromagnet is ONLY used to pickup.  I guess I didn't look through it too closely.
comments.author: gddeen

comments.text: It's not a bistable latching mechanism, good idea to also use permanent magnets on the middle carriage. I did looked at electromagnets that attract while not powered, but those are more expensive. At this point i only did 2 hours test prints (dual extrusion so about 50% of the time powered), those were successful. I still have to test longer prints and monitor temperature of the magnets. (electromagnet spec, 12V  3,5W  limit temperature 130°C)
comments.author: gddeen

comments.text: How do you handle heat dissipation of the electromagnets? Those puppies get toasty after a while powered on. How does it handle collisions with curled prints and other minor artifacts?
comments.author: oliasmage

comments.text: The specs of the electromagnet say a limit temperature of 130°C, i think i havent reached that yet. I still have to test longer prints and monitor the temperature. I will report back if i did some longer tests and got more information, also see my reply to gddeen above.
comments.author: oliasmage

comments.text: 130 is way too much for printed parts in which you enclose them, you need to keep it under 50 for pla, under 80 for abs - my experience with couple of melted motor holders...
comments.author: Jellebross

comments.text: After about an hour the temperature of the electromagnet got to an stable 65°C, so i am pretty happy about that. But i think cheaper magnets such as those from china have an worse efficiency ratio and will get hotter.
comments.author: ariuskooo

comments.text:
I have a old abs carriages that holds two e3d v6 and the heater blocks were only 3 mm away from abs parts. They have run for many hours at 240+ degrees and i never saw any deformations. So i hoped they can handle 130 degrees even enclosed.
I hope to test it for a long run this week and see how it goes.

description.text:
This simple jig can be used for hobbing the teeth on a filament drive gear. Rather than the usual method of cutting teeth with a tap, this jig helps you create a series of overlapping spot drills that result in sharp, deep teeth that grab securely and eject debris. It is scaled for use with 8mm dia. rod.

Watch it in use at: https://youtu.be/E4LW0ZjslYc

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

It's best use 3 perimeters/shells to make it a little sturdier.

Print out both the collet and holder piece. Screw the holder piece to a board (using two 8-32 screws, 1/2" spacing) that can be clamped to your drill press. Tap an 8-32 thread in the collet for a set screw.

To use, clamp the holder in place so that the drill bit is centered over the rod cradle in the holder. I used a 1/8" diameter mill-drill bit with a 90 deg. tip angle, but you can also use a center drill. Clamp your 8mm rod in place in the collet with the set screw and then set your drill stop so that you are only drilling about 0.5mm deep. Place the collet in the holder, aligning the nub on the holder with one of the indexing notches in the collet. Drill spot drill holes in all 16 positions. Reset the drill stop depth to 1mm and then re-drill all 16 positions.

description.text:
Another wonderful project by thinkpool. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1416128

My goal was to get the lizard to move forward. Was able to get final version to move
13" forward by rolling the rubber band onto the wheel+tire with modest tension. It will
do a wheelie if it's to taunt.

The A Team:
green; Stock arbor wheel, under mount rubber band, centering hole in button
red; full arbor wheel, nostrils, removed rubber band under mount.
gold; full arbor wheel, top mount rubber band, rubber band tire, tongue & upper mouth.

For the tire to work, a person needs to hold the installed back wheel down on a flat surface and apply heat (match) to each leg until they relax and cool. Then install the tire.

1.75 filament alignment holes can be cleaned out with a 5/64 drill bit. Axle hole in back
can be cleaned out with a small rotary bit.

Need to slow the print speed at wheel axle and legs.

The wheels have been sliced for no support printing.

description.text:
These parts go on the middle 4 pillars of the ZMR250 quadcopter frame.
When assembled, they create a protective cage around the battery to stop it from being damaged during a crash.

If used with padding, it will stop the battery from rattling around, keep its self closed and be easy to open when needing to access the battery.

This is designed to fit the Turnigy Nanotech 1300mAh 3S LiPo battery, but it may fit others of similar size.

Printed on an Ultimaker Original

http://jaydlawrence.co.uk/zmr250-quadcopter-protective-battery-cage/

title: Hot End Heat Sink Fan Duct for Zonestar P802Q (Prusa i3)

description.text:
With this fan duct you can improve the hot end cooling of a Zonestar P802Q. The fan duct was designed for a hot end heat sink with a diameter of 22.2 mm and a 40 mm fan (= original parts of P802Q). As you see on the pictures the fan duct will be installed inside of the metal box of the extruder. The installation is a bit tricky because there is not much space. I considered the screw head of the X-bearing (SCS8UU) and the rectangle nozzle heater. That's the reason for the dimples and asymmetric design.

Installation remarks:
Pay attention that the screw of the Teflon tube can be screwed in easily (let the fan screws loosely at first). The thread of the heat sink and the bore of the extruder housing have to be concentric. If not, you have to move the fan duct a bit up or down to bring the dimples of the fan duct at the position of screw heads of the X-bearing . After the Teflon tube is installed tighten the fan screws.

Optional: You can use some super glue to fix the M3 nut on the fan duct (might facilitate the installation).

comments.text: What kind of improvement did it make?
comments.author: ioquatix

author: widddo

print_settings.Notes:: Print two copies of the spindle, unless you use your own variation to retain the spool.

title: Flux Delta external filament spool holder

description.text:
Flux Delta printers have a recess for smaller spools, but a one kg spool won't fit. This spool holder is designed more-or-less on the fly to hold larger spools. It clips over the front (relative to the cover hinge) and is slightly sloped on the back side to prevent interference with the extruder carriage. The back side of the clip fits precisely over the cover latch and is sized to fit equally well on the top of the printer. There is very little movement or play in the clip portion. I suspect that one could add a layer of masking tape to make a firmer fit.

The SCAD files are included, but be warned.

I am not a programmer. I will never say I know what I'm doing. I've been learning OpenSCAD with each model I construct and I try to implement common accepted practices in my code.

There may be duplication of code in these files. There are certainly references from one part to the other and there's no automation to ensure that when a value is changed in one that it will be adjusted in the other. I can assure that such changes will not happen.

This model has been created to fit my printer and my printer settings. To get this far, I frequently chopped off portions of the model in OpenSCAD to print and test fit. Three or four partial prints for the top clip, two partial prints for the "socket" for the spindle and three prints to ensure that the spindle would fit the scrap aluminum I have in my scrap pile.

I cut the tubing to six inches long to allow me to drill holes for clips or pins to retain the spool. The tubing in this model is 1.125 inches diameter, although the code will not reflect that figure. This is a result of the test print. I used a lot of TLAR to make this model.

I suspect that one could make some modifications to the model to use with other printers. The design is far from optimal, but it looks like it's going to work. If not, I'll change something and build a variation.

I can see in the published version that the preview portion of OpenSCAD is showing artifacts where none exist. I did not use the common "fudge" figure to make larger the difference actions, so there are "shadows" in the photos here that have no impact on the print, nor on the rendered model in OpenSCAD.

It's my first contribution to Thingiverse and I hope others will make good use of it.

Printer:

Flux Delta

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.250

Infill:

20% (arbitrary)

Notes:

Print two copies of the spindle, unless you use your own variation to retain the spool.

Simple final steps

I'll be adding epoxy to secure the tubing on the clip end.
I'll be drilling holes at the opposite end of the tubing to accept retention clips (from my scrap pile). I could certainly build something via 3d printing, but why?

Update to this build. I've found that the feed tube for the Flux Delta wants to "wander about" when connected to the external spool. There is insufficient height to the clip to drill a guide hole for the feed tube. One could increase the wall thickness and subtract a cylinder for the guide tube if desired.

I routed the feed tube over the clip and stuck it in place with push-pins. Adhesive tape didn't stick well enough.

comments.text: What did you do to guide the filament to the extruder properly? I'm having trouble with a similar spool holder that keeps wrapping itself around the roller.
comments.author: jimustanguitar

comments.text: It was a poorly engineered solution, in my opinion, but I used a pair of push pins to hold the guide tube to the top of the holder. I've since sold the printer, but I would have increased the thickness of the section and either drilled or printed a hole for the tube to pass through.
comments.author: jimustanguitar

remixed_from.author: jonaskuehling
remixed_from.title: Greg's Wade reloaded - Guidler, Tilt Screws, Fishbone Gears

title: Herringbone Prusa i3 Reworked Greg's Extruder

description.text:
The extruder was iteratively modified to address the following issues:

1) The old Greg's big gear does not properly trap the 8mm bolt head. These gears were replaced with the herringbone gear set.

2) The base of the extruder (where it mounts to the x-carriage) was thickened as the large herringbone gear has a larger OD than the Greg's big gear. This larger OD prevented attaching the extruder body to the x-carriage. The thickened base now allows the large herringbone gear to rotate freely.

3) Recesses were added to the extruder body to allow 3mm cap screws to sit flush with the gear-facing side when attaching the motor so that the screw heads did not interfere with movement of the large gear. This was a feature previously included on the Greg's / Wade's extruder body.

4) Recesses and nut traps were added to the J-head extruder mount to eliminate interference with the large herringbone gear.

5) The idler tab was modified to include a thumb tab for easy access to the hobbed bolt. The bolt holes for the tension screws were also increased in size to reduce binding on the threads when accessing the hobbed bolt.

6) A secondary mounting point was added at the back of the J-head mount to accommodate a parts cooling fan.

7) Mounting holes were added into the X-carriage and the extruder body to secure a 'finger' to trigger the X-limit-switch. This finger is compatible with my drop-in replacement for the Prusa i3 Reloaded X-Motor-End part.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

none
The thumb tab for the extruder idler was inspired by the Robo 3D R1 remix of the Greg's extruder.

comments.author: rocketbob

comments.text: It is designed for 1.75 mm filament but you can easily ream out the hole with a 3 mm bit.

Need a safe and inexpensive way to know if there's hazardous chemicals in the air after an earthquake, train derailment, industrial fire, etc.? Slide a standard hazmat card into the slot, mount it on your Inspire 1, and fly it around the area in question from a safe distance. Adds about 30g of weight, which is trivial for the I1. May your card always come back clean!

This version uses my Inspire 1 "GoPro" mount system, but if you just want to attach it with tape or DualLock then this version is the one you want.

I bought my card here, but they're easily found elsewhere. Just search for "HazMat Smart Strip."

If you don't have access to a 3D printer, Shapeways will print this for you.

description.text:
It's the amazing, self-piloting Starbug space bus! Ride to your next intergalactic corporate meeting in style, safety, and comfort! This miniature vehicle/terrain piece was designed for Wayfarer Tactics, our fast, modular (as in "fully customizable") miniature gaming rules. If you want to check it out, it's totally free here on our site, so give it a download!. It is, of course, useful for any 15mm scale miniature wargame or RPG. If you want 28mm scale versions, just increase the size by 180%!

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

description.text:
This is a bucket crane I printed as part of a bucket crane robo-car project. See the complete robo car video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AAIU-lIyx6k

It requires some assembly. See assembled.stl for the assembled bucket crane (without the parts connecting to stepper motor).

Printer:

ForgerTech 2020

Resolution:

0.3mm

Notes:

I found it really tricky to make the parts fit with lego axles. You might need to adjust some settings to get a good fit.

Gears connecting to the stepper motor. Gears from the other side. Assembly Instructions

You will need to print the following parts:

  • 2 base
  • 2 lower_arm
  • 1 upper_arm_main
  • 1 upper_arm_pulley
  • 1 upper_arm_fork
  • 1 bucket

Two strings of about 1 foot long each, for connecting the upper and lower pulleys.
8 3mm screws of about 10mm length, and 2 of 12mm length.

You also need 2 lego gears with 24 teeth and 10 teeth, 3 lego axles, 15 mm, 40mm and 65mm.

In addition, if you want to use the gears to connect to the stepper motor, you need:

  • 1 stepper_rack
  • 1 gear_rack
  • 1 coupler

After printing, you need to glue the upper_arm_pulley to upper_arm_main. Make sure the knobs on the pulleys are aligned.

You might need to check the fitting of the holes with lego axles. Some filing with a needle file might be required to get the axles in. Similarly, I also run a 5mm drill bit through the holes to make sure the axles can turn smoothly.

The most important step is to connect the pulleys with string, so that when the lower arm is turning, the pulley in the base drives the upper pulley to turn as well. The radius of the pulleys have a ratio about 9:5, so that when the lower arm rotate 100 degrees, the upper pulley rotates 180 degrees to up raise the bucket straight up.

I first tie the strings around the knobs on the two upper arm pulleys. Then connect the upper arm to the lower arms with the 40mm lego axle, and connect lower arms to the bases with the 65mm lego axle. Wrap the strings around to the base pulleys. Carefully get the two ends through the small gap between the pulley and base. This takes some patience. I used a wire to help get the strings through. After both ends are in, put a 3x12mm screws through the center holes at the bottom of the base piece, to fasten the strings.

Use the other 4 screw holes on the base pieces to attach them to your truck or wherever you are attaching the bucket crane. After this, turn the axle at the base, you should see the lower arm and upper arm rising up together.

The next step is to attach the upper_arm_fork to the upper_arm_main. Again, a little bit filing might be needed to get a snug fit. I put a small screw through the hole to connect them. Glue will also work.

The last step is to put the bucket into the fork. Make sure the bucket can turn freely, or you have to do some filing again.

Hope this is helpful.

description.text:
Replacement outlet covers for the one (1) and three (3) button Honewell Tap-lite light switches. To my knowledge these outlets and their covers have been discontinued so that getting replacement switch covers is a chore.

Infill patterns are visible with transparent filament, but they actually look pretty good that way.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Have printed these on both a Makerbot Replicator 2 and a NewMatter MOD-t.

These prints can produces "stringy" bridges, but it's all underneath.
You can either room these with the supports or leave them.

Front view Backview: Backview. Some bridge strings visible after support removal. Easy removed if more transparency desired with transparent filament

comments.text: Hi:  I scour the internet (and Ebay) for these 1950's Honeywell Tap-lite switch covers.  I have a classic mid-century modern house that has these switches throughout.  I don't know if you are familiar with the originals but they were made to take a thin cardboard or heavy paper liner (the color or design of your choice)!  My houe was built in 1952 so they are probably the earliest line-voltage tap lights.  The buttons on the switches were a satin metallic gold and they're in fine shape.  However I have 3 or 4 single covers that have a crack in them.  Would love to replace them but I'm not sure if the rough 'patterned' surface on the inside would match the others.....also the originals have a gold paper liner (which I could replace on all of them).  The odd thing is:  I don't think my covers have convex edges at the top and bottom; rather, I think they're flat. I'm not at the house right now so I will look later. I also think I have one double cover with crack or chip in it.  So, here are a few questions:  Do you make these to sell---if so how much?  I would probably have to replace all of them so they would match.  I think there are 8 singles and 2 doubles (I could send you a double cover for measurements).  Can you make them with a smooth surface on the inside?  Do these just stay on by tension/pressure against the base of button, like the originals?  So many queries!  I look forward to your reply.    Thanks, Terri

title: True Fruits Spice Shaker Insert // True Fruits Gewürzstreuer-Einsatz

description.text:
Deutsche Version unten

Are you collecting True Fruits Smoothie jars like me?
I started putting herbs and spices in the empty jars some time ago before i had a 3D printer and wondered why i could not get someting online to make it easier to sprinke them onto my food.
So, now i designed this Insert.

Features:

  • Just insert to a (small) True Fruits Jar
  • good for powders, like curry or pepper. will make another version for herbs soon
  • as it sits inside the jar, original lid goes just on top making an air-tight seal to keep the spices fresh

-- Work in Progress --
Current Problems: As it sits pretty tight inside the jar, its pretty difficult to get it out again...
currently, prying it out with a paper clip works, but I'm looking into finding improvements to make removal easier

I recomment printing with a food-grade filament!

====================

Sammeln sich in deinem Schrank auch die True Fruts Smoothie-Gläser, wie bei mir?Ich habe angefangen, darin Kräuter und Gewürze aufzubewahren, lange bevor ich einen 3D-Drucker hatte und habe mich gewunder, dass niemand auf die Idee kam, einen Gewürzstreuer-Einsatz dafür zu machen.
Jetzt habe ich daher diesen Einsatz erstellt.

Features:

  • Einfach in ein (kleines) True Fruits Smoothie-Glas einsetzen
  • Passend für feine Gewürzpulver, wie Pfeffer oder Curry. Eine grobe Version für getrocknete Kräuter folgt demnächst.
  • Da es im Flaschenhans sitzt, passt der originale Deckel weiterhin und sorgt dafür, dass eure Gewürze und Kräuter dicht verschlossen lange frisch bleiben

-- Work in Progress --
Aktuelle Probleme: Der Einsatz sitzt ziemlich fest im Glas (muss er auch, damit er nicht mitsamt den Gewürzen im Essen landet). Daher ist er ziemlich schwer zu entfernen.
Ich benutze aktuell eine Büroklammer, um ihn herauszuziehen, suche aber nach Verbesserungen, um das Entfernen zu erleichtern.

Ich empfehle die Verwendung von Lebensmittelechtem Filamement!

This is a device that you can make to light up the inside of your MakerBot.  By using some LEDs, a couple resistors and the MakerBot power supply, you can give your MakerBot that cool glowing interior.  It is designed to snap into the slots on the top of the MakerBot, and be wired to the 12V line of the MakerBot power supply using unused HDD connectors.  It is easy to print up a pair and give it a try!

• Print a pair of Lightbars, using the attached STL file. It is very forgiving, and can be printed at about any fill density and will still work.

  • LEDs are inserted into the Lightbar. They should be a snug fit, if you use 5mm LEDs like I did. I got mine from All Electronics: http://www.allelectronics.com/make-a-store/item/LED-127/ULTRABRIGHT-WHITE-LED-5MM-15-DEG/1.html

  • Solder the LEDs together. How exactly you do this will depend on the exact specifications that you use. Check out this flickr.com photoset for some more details: http://www.flickr.com/photos/[email protected]/sets/72157622993771738/

  • Add a plug to attach the Lightbars to your MakerBot power supply - if you do it the way I did, you use the 12V line. That way when you power up your machine, it lights up the interior, too.

  • Enjoy!
Same as http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14462 but bigger and with some supports that act as handles.
Print, Cut Cookies, Eat Cookies.

title: RepRap Prusa i3 Lighted Power Switch Panel

description.text:
I needed a way to control the ATX power supply connected to my Prusa Mendel i2 and I wanted to be able to turn on or off the LEDs in my printer enclosure as well as turning on or off my cooling fans. I built this box to house all of the different switches that control my printer.

This box is made out of 4 different parts that sandwich together. I used standard SPST ON/OFF 2-pin black head rectangular rocker switches like you might find in an ATX power supply.

The round posts on the inside of the switch plate hold 5mm LEDs. See photo for example of finished project.

I used the transparent tape on a Dymo LetraTag label maker for the switch labels.

comments.text: A very clever design. Just what (I didn't know) I needed! I think I'll make one and remix it for old fashioned chrome toggle switches.

description.text:
Micro-SD Card Holder

  1. Print at least one holder
  2. Print one lid
  3. Place SD Cards inside
  4. Use the lid

I couldn't believe that I couldn't find a microSD card holder that I liked on here. I took a few minutes and designed what I had in mind. The spacing between the cards is enough that you should be able to remove your card without tweezers.

The bases are stackable. Just two stacks will retain 10 cards. It may not be clear from the picture, but the bases actually clip together along with the lid. These features were designed to be retaining so that nothing falls out.

title: Improved Holder for Height Adjustable Fan Duct (Zonestar P802Q)

description.text:
I really like the design of rumlyne [1]. The benefit of this design is, that you can easily remove the ring-shaped fan duct (e.g. if you print ABS and don't need a fan duct or if you are levelling the bed of the printer) Unfortunately you always have to remove the fan to adjust the height. That's why I created a version of a holder with adjusting screws from above. Further more I added a spacer for my autolevel sensor.

Variation to rumlyne-design:
Part "Halterung"

  • height adjusting screws from above
  • more robust
  • thicker shoe (because the fan duct was a bit too loose)
  • considered screw heads of the part "Winkel" at the backside of the part "Halterung"
  • smaller bore holes for the fan screws.

Part Winkel:

  • other bore holes
  • wider (around 14 mm)
  • height only 7 mm (instead of 9 mm), otherwise the original M3 screws of Zonestar are to small.

New Part:

  • AutoLevelSpacer.stl

Remarks:

  • I used only the idea and some dimensions of [1] for this completely new designed parts.
  • You also need to download the part Fan_Duct_DuctV2.stl from [1]
  • "WH" are the initials of my name. I also uploaded a version without that artistic nonesense (version "without branding").

Soon I will upload some more pictures.

[1] http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1328117

title: 1:100 M2HB .50 cal machinegun, vehicle mount (Flames of War)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A stand-alone M2HB machinegun for general 1:100/Flames of War-scale models, taken from m_bergman's M5A1 halftrack and modified with additional detail, slightly increased in size, and generally made to be as close-as-possible a replacement for the official FoW .50 cal. The pics show this attached to his M4A3E8 "Easy Eight" Sherman model(s), but is sized to work just fine with any other turrets/etc.

The "v1" is slightly smaller than the "v2", as well has having some other minor model differences. Depending on your printer and skill the v1 may prove easier (and nicer-looking) to print than the v2; as usual, YMMV.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

These print at a variety of settings; the ones in my pics are 0.15mm layer height and 0.3mm width (I used a 0.4mm nozzle, with line width reduced to 0.3mm), although you can get away with 0.2mm height/0.4mm width as well. Play around with it, number of perimeters, infill, etc.

A raft and supports are strongly recommended, if not absolutely required. I included a pic of the raft/support setup that I used - as you can see, it's probably 3x the material of the actual models (which I usually print 6+ at a time), but it keeps them looking good in the end.

There are a few good universal mounts that have been made for Alted's Mostly Printed CNC. I could not get my favorite to fit well so I made a simple plate to bolt on to the DW660 mounts. It started with me drilling some holes in a scrap piece of plastic then I started playing with TinkerCad. The mounts are not perfect and I still need to clean up the MK8 mount a little but I thought I would share them since maybe someone else could use them.
Thanks to Ryan for making such a great machine and to all the designers of great mounts that I remixed to use. If I missed someone for credit, let me know as it is not intentional.

My CNC router has a 2'x2' working ares so for my stool I used a 2'x2'x3/4" piece of plywood and some standard elmer's carpenter's glue.  The seat is 12"x14" and the base is 15"x17". It sits 18" off the ground with a footrest 6" off the ground.  
The stool is incredibly sturdy, I weigh about 230lbs and there is no signs of stress on the stool.  I'm sure it will support at least 300lbs.  
Once the glue has fully cured it will get a good sanding and a nice stain.  
Instructions:  
The seat is nested into the footrest separated by 1/8".  I used a 1/8" router bit.  The inside corners of the slots and tongues were drilled out   by the router before cutting out the parts to ensure a proper fit (look closely at the photos).  
If the tolerances of your tongues and slots don't make for a tight fit you may want to use foaming gorilla glue to help fill the gap.  
When assembling the chair make the base first.  Apply a generous amount of glue to the slots in the foot rest and legs before joining, then apply glue to the tongues of the legs and fit the seat on top. For maximum strength, ensure there is glue on all mating surfaces. Wipe up the excess glue.  I used some scrap dowels wedged between the legs rather than clamping each individual leg and then I set my heavy tool box on top and let the glue cure for 2 hours before testing.  Let the glue cure for a full 24 hours before sanding and staining.

comments.text: The bit size is 1/8".

description.text: This is a model to help teach maneuvers for whitewater kayaking. The model can edge the boat from side to side as well as twist the torso from left and right. To build the model, print one of each part, and two posts.

Printer:

DaVinci Jr.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

5%

Notes:

Supports are needed for the bow, stern, shoulders, torso, and head files.

Assembly

Slide the hexagonal axel through the torso. Insert the axel into the bow of the kayak along with the two posts. Attach the stern to the posts and axel. Slide the shoulders onto the torso and attach the head on top. Slide the paddle shaft through the holes on the shoulder part and attach the paddles to the ends. I recommend using a small amount of glue to hold the axel, posts, paddles, and head in place. Be carful not to get glue on the parts of the torso and shoulders that pivot.

I made a small change in "The simplest spool holder".
The top bar has a round top and the bottom are two individual triangular blocks with slots in them. This works really well and can be printed on a small printer platform like my printrbot simple if you split the struts into individual item.

comments.text: What spool size does it fit?
comments.author: kamnxt

comments.text: Just FYI; the reason I used a rectangular bar at the top was so it would print at higher speed and it really has a trivial affect on the friction of the wheel turning IMO. Having it rounded means you either have to print slower, or risk shaking the piece from from the print bed.
comments.author: CTRLurself

comments.text: Good point, it was more of a test to make it round. It might even have more friction since more of the role is in contact with the top bar.
comments.author: CTRLurself

comments.text: On my replicator 2 I did mine at 100mm/s printing, 100mm/s jog - at that speed a rounded bar like that makes my whole desk shake and the part break free, hence the utterly minimalist design. I just use Kapton tape for now, but I'm trying out different build surfaces.

I wanted to use the Ultimaker robot in an OpenSCAD design, but OpenSCAD couldn't handle it. After several simplication iterations in meshlab, and several times through netfabb, this model is finally ready for use in OpenSCAD. It was a little sad reducing the quality so much on such a fine model but hey, the mash ups must go on!
I've included the simplified original, a version with the back flattened, an SVG outline, and a DXF for linear extrusion.
EDIT: I just added a version without the hole in the back of the head.

• Import into OpenSCAD
  • Do a happy dance
  • Mash up!

description.text:
I remixed these as the nuts were always being pulled out when the GoPro is tripod screw is torqued.
These mounts allow use of standard and lock-nuts and the nuts will not slip when tightened. Marked as W.I.P. since I have not tested the STD Nut adapter model as I only have a lock-nut handy. If I can find a standard 1/4-20 nut I will adjust the dimensions in the model to reflect proper sizing (if needed).

I've included the .skp files for easier editing/remixing.

Depending on your tripod, a longer bolt may be required. Sadly, the bolt on my cheapo tripod is too short but its nothing that can't be fixed with a quick trip to the hardware store (or a parts bin of mine!)

This is a beefier version of the 18mm inductive sensor mount for the circular fan.

The support columns have been beefed up for added strength.

The bolt holes have been enlargened for more wiggle room. This allows for better placement of the bracket in case you have a cheaper kit that doesn't match up completely or is slightly off.

Printer:

HICTOP Prusa I3

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

100

Notes:

Use 80-100% infill for the strongest part possible. Print using ABS or PLA.

Supports are needed for the over hang and a rafts will help overall.

comments.text:
Thank you for your design.
It works nice

title: Diced Cube (3D Printed Version)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Diced Cube is a puzzle I created a few years ago with 27 dice, hence the name. They were glued into 9 L's that when assembled into a cube would have each number facing the same direction as the original die.
I've also made a lasercut wood version, but it is SUPER tedious to build, so I decided to craft one in 3D.

UPDATE: I've removed the separate piece files in favor of the All-In-One which is now uploaded with much better symbols. Circle/Square/Diamond and Dotted versions of each for the opposite sides. No pics for the as-yet-unbuilt new one, but the STL will show you the new symbols. :-)

{Ignore}-->[Apologies for all the separate files, but my M3D doesn't understand how to printed unconnected models, and the "single file" has the old (ugly) symbols on it so I'm not sharing that one. Maybe later if there's a demand for it. :-) ]

As far as sharing goes, feel free to make a set for you own enjoyment, but if you do make a set for sale of somebody else, please send some green stuff my way. This is one of my first babies and I'm still kind of protective of it. ;-)

Printer:

M3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

The higher the better

Infill:

Light

Notes:

In most cases, I'd have to say that Rafts are NOT recommended. Supports are not needed for this unless you're making it bigger than the designed 1/2" reference cube, or, you like gouging out the supports from tiny crevices.

M3D is S.L.O.W so I did this with the next to lowest resolution, but higher is definitely better. Also, more infill will add better heft to the pieces.

As usual stuff

All you really need to do is clean off the burrs that inevitably occur.

From Dice to Wood to PLA

As mentioned before, this was originally a Dice puzzle, but due to materials, I created it with wood, and now PLA.
For the pattern of L's, I used Lego bricks to play with positioning until they formed an interesting pattern for a cube. After that, it was just a matter of gluing the dice into the correct configurations.

Symbols or whatever.

I made this one out of Silver because I'm still playing/learning with my M3D, but this would look awesome in 9 different colors.

Even though the original used dice, I've designed this one with "matching" symbols that are easily differentiated. The wood version can be made with any set of six "things" you'd like. Number, Letters, Icons.... whatever. :-)

Oh, yeah! And each iteration usually ends up being a different pattern to the solution. :-/

comments.text: Let me know if any of you great folks Make and Solve this one. :-)
comments.author: PArtzzles

author: PArtzzles

print_settings.Notes:: Printed with Inland Orange ABS at 235 degrees with 100 degree bed

description.text:
I was helping out a friend who has a QUBD OneUp with some assembly issues so I started tinkering.

At one point I found I needed a fan bracket that would hold the stock fan, a duct and also provide a convenient place to mount the Open Cable Chain. I also had started using the Accessible/Viewable/Cleanable Extruder which offsets the hotend from the NEMA motor. I was also intrigued by the Fan duct on/off valve and found that with some trimming it provided more focused cooling than just hanging the fan out there.

The bracket has a cutout for the wires for the extruder motor to be routed out the bottom which gathers nicely with the fan and hotend wiring to be sent through the cable chain. All parts printed out of ABS on a Rostock Max V2.

The only caveat I have found so far is the ducting hangs pretty low so clearances with the bed mounting and printer frame itself need to be checked closely.

Printer:

This is a wall mount for the Google Fiber Router. This router measures ~ 7 5/8" X 7 5/8" X 1 5/8" with feet. I don't use the wifi function, so positioning is unimportant to me. I put 3 oval cut-outs in the mount in an attempt to use a little less PLA. Also I provided a cut-out for the blue status indicator on the corner of the router. I printed it with 10% fill and no support. On my printer it took about 4 hours to print.

title: Second attempt for set screw 6-40 Schlage lock

description.text:
This is to replace the set screws in a Schlage lock so it can be re-pinned frequently without concern that the regular steel set screws will cross-thread and bite into the softer brass of the lock. PLA should be harmless.

This was made with Mike Linus' lovely nut 'n bolt customizer, but I may have pushed it beyond its usable range. I doubt my printers can spit this out, and I have likely messed it up in some other way, too.

I'll try to run off a copy tomorrow and tweak it over the next weekend.
